subject: Redirect "apt-get install -y" stdin to /dev/null
commit_message:
Redirect "apt-get install -y" stdin to /dev/null

According to debian bug 728775 [1] apt-get by design will consume stdin
(even when not run interactively).

When the run-aio-build.sh script is used as part of a curl-pipe-bash
such as described in the quick start docs [2] apt-get will effectively
halt execution of the script after installing git. The next time the
script is run it will get past the step because git is now installed and
apt-get no longer consumes stdin. In addition to run-aio-build.sh,
bootstrap-aio.sh and bootstrap-ansible.sh call apt-get and so exhibit
the same behaviour when called by run-aio-build.sh when used as part of
a curl-pipe-bash.

In addition to apt-get install -y, apt-get purge -y exhibits the same
behaviour.

The result for the end user is they must run the command multiple times
to get it to work.

Using the bash method to close stdin (0<&- [3]) causes apt-get to print
out "E: Write error - write (14: Bad address)" and fail. The solution is
to explicitly set stdin to nothing, such as "echo '' | apt-get ..." or
"apt-get ... < /dev/null". The latter is chosen for its aesthetics.

yum install -y does not exhibit this behaviour and so does not require
its stdin redirected.

[1] https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=728775
[2] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/openstack-ansible/developer-docs/quickstart-aio.html#running-an-aio-build-in-one-step
[3] http://www.tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/io-redirection.html

Change-Id: I57484590e257956e1d1bc8e10ce8a35207622672
Closes-Bug: 1504546
(cherry picked from commit 05f10294e64cf113020442ea1094e25d13ded2d9)

Fixed multiple py34 gate issues

1. Scope mock of 'open' to module

By mocking 'open' at the module level, we can avoid affecting
'open' calls from other modules.

2. Stop using LOG.exception in contexts with no sys.exc_info set

Python 3.4 logger fills in record.exc_info with sys.exc_info() result
[1], and then it uses it to determine the current exception [2] to
append to the log message. Since there is no exception, exc_info[1] is
None, and we get AttributeError inside traceback module.

It's actually a bug in Python interpreter that it attempt to access the
attribute when there is no exception. It turns out that it's fixed in
latest master of cPython [3] (the intent of the patch does not seem
relevant, but it removes the offending code while reshuffling the code).
Note that now cPython correctly checks the exception value before
accessing its attributes [4].

The patch in cPython that resulted in the failure is [5] and is present
since initial Python 3k releases.

The patch in fixtures that broke us is [6].

[1]: https://hg.python.org/cpython/file/tip/Lib/logging/__init__.py#l1412
[2]: https://hg.python.org/cpython/file/tip/Lib/logging/__init__.py#l575

[4]: https://hg.python.org/cpython/rev/73afda5a4e4c#l6.484
[5]: https://hg.python.org/cpython/rev/2ee09afee126
[6]: https://github.com/testing-cabal/fixtures/commit/67dd2956943261e845a866dab155208c51da937e

subject: Fix RPC API compat for 1.29 upgrade
commit_message:
Fix RPC API compat for 1.29 upgrade

This adds a keyword argument "return_dict" to the server side of
the vendor_passthru and driver_vendor_passthru RPC methods,
defaulting to False. The RPC client passes True if it can send
version 1.29, and False otherwise. If return_dict is True, it
will return the dict response that was introduced in version
1.29, and if False will return the tuple response that existed
before 1.29.

By having return_dict default to False if not passed, RPC clients
that are not yet at 1.29 will be compatible with a server at 1.29
or above. This removes a major blocker to doing rolling upgrades,
though it is important to note that rolling upgrades are not yet
officially supported.

Note that we do *not* bump the RPC version for this change, as
doing so would defeat the purpose of this bugfix.

Change-Id: I72375be0596d20dcb87923d441a17ff93d9df9dc
Closes-Bug: #1502903

subject: Notify nova when ports are ready
commit_message:
Notify nova when ports are ready

The following patch adds a callback from neutron to nova that notifies nova
when a port for an instance is *ready to be used*. After nova receives this
event it will then start the instance in a hope that when it comes up
its networking should be in working order.

NOTE: *ready to be used* currently means that a plugin changes the status
in the db associated with a port from:
NO_VALUE/PORT_STATUS_DOWN/PORT_STATUS_ACTIVE to ACTIVE/ERROR.

Neutron will then signal nova: network_vif_plugged:<status> where status
will either be 'completed' or 'failed' given the neutron port status.

Neutron also notifies nova when a port goes from status:
PORT_STATUS_ACTIVE to PORT_STATUS_DOWN and sends nova a network_vif_unplugged
event.

Currently this patch breaks multiregion support (i.e previously you could
back multiple nova regions by one neutron server) though now since neutron
needs to notify nova we'll need to add a way to determine which region a
given port is in.

For now the work around for this would be to set: notify_nova_port_active=False
in neutron to prevent neutron from sending the notification and setting:
vif_plugging_is_fatal=False in nova.conf. Doing this will keep the current
interaction where an instance will be booted without waiting for the network
to be ready.

DocImpact

implements blueprint: nova-event-callback

subject: Fix Python 3 support for eventlet monkey-patching
commit_message:
Fix Python 3 support for eventlet monkey-patching

Use eventlet.green.subprocess if eventlet is used and enable eventlet
tests on Python 3.

This change adds oslo_rootwrap.subprocess which is
eventlet.green.subprocess if eventlet monkey-patching is enabled or
if the TEST_EVENTLET environment variable is set, or subprocess of
the Python standard library otherwise.

When eventlet is used (with monkey-patching or not), it's more
reliable to use eventlet.green.subprocess instead of using directly
subprocess from the Python standard library.

On Python 2, it "works" to use directly subprocess: subprocess.Popen
calls os.pipe() and os.fdopen(fd) which are both monkey-patched. On
Python 3, it doesn't work because subprocess uses os.pipe() and
io.open(fd), and the io module is *not* monkey-patched at all.

subject: Use current branch for devstack/projects
commit_message:
Use current branch for devstack/projects

This changes defaults the behaviour to use the current branch of
devstack and each project, unless the corresponding environment
variable is set.

When support for variables such as TROVE_BRANCH was added, an
unintended side-effect was introduced.  In the use case of
testing a changeset by creating a new branch for the checkout,
redstack would switch the repo back to master, if the
TROVE_BRANCH variable was not explicitly set.  This forces the
developer/tester to set the variable - if they forget they will
end up inadvertently testing the master branch.

For example, doing the following would not give the
expected result:

cd /opt/stack/trove
git fetch ssh://<fetch_cmd> && git checkout FETCH_HEAD
git checkout -b new_branch
cd ~/trove-integration/scripts
./redstack install

Redstack in this case would switch the repo back to master,
so you would need to remember to add 'TROVE_BRANCH=newbranch'
before the install command.

This fix makes sure that the repo is only switched if one of the
variables is actually set.

Change-Id: I4e74f7c7222548e4e2ec8ce02d29a610d2f2e1da

data instead of comparing the serialized JSON data which depends on

This change makes the code more readable, but it was written to port

now randomized by default, so dictionary items are serialized in a

enough to have a reliable JSON serialized ouput in all cases.

subject: libvirt: use log file and serial console at the same time
commit_message:
libvirt: use log file and serial console at the same time

The config option "[serial_console].enabled" is used as a switch by
the libvirt driver to determine if EITHER the instance log file OR
the serial console should be created as a device for the guest.
Over the last months I was not able to get an answer why this design
was chosen. Frankly, I believe that it is a bug. Because I couldn't
find any "prove" that the current implementation is "wrong", I have
chosen the "blueprint way" to commit this change.

To be precise: If cloud admins set the compute node config option
"[serial_console].enabled" to "True", they prevent that the REST API
for the "os-getConsoleOutput" action for guests on these compute nodes
will return anything (because nothing gets logged). End users, who call
that REST API, will sometimes get a result and sometimes not, depending
on the configuration of the host where the instance gets scheduled to.

This patch set will allow the creation of BOTH devices (log file AND
serial console) for the guest. Which means that the REST API action
"os-getConsoleOutput" will return a result, even if the "serial console"
feature was enabled or not.

UpgradeImpact:
Instances, which get launched on compute nodes which have this patch,
will have 2 devices ("tcp" AND "file") instead of the 1 device
("tcp" OR "file") they get without this patch. Existing instances
which get migrated to a patched host, won't get the additional device
unless they get rebuild. Guests which were already built with multiple
serial devices (through flavor extra specs or image metadata) could
exceed the upper limit of 4 serial devices after a rebuild. Due to
bug 1425640, which says that the REST API only returns the very first
serial console device, I believe that this is not yet really exploited
by customers.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-log-file-and-serial-console

subject: Properly detect backing instance is gone
commit_message:
Properly detect backing instance is gone

The instance_manager's current caching of instance_info only happens
once and is never refreshed.  This causes update_state() to not notice
a backing instance is gone until it fails a API liveliness check.

This fixes it by updating the instance_info on every run of ensure_cache(),
in the same way it does for the router_obj.  This will properly detect
a backing instance is gone and rebuild the router without the slow
failing liveliness check.

Fixing this introduces a race where we try to check the API server of
a booted instance that does not yet have ports associated.  This also
fixes this by considering instances with no management port to still
be in the booting state.

subject: vmware: use cache_prefix to preserve cache directory
commit_message:
vmware: use cache_prefix to preserve cache directory

Currently value of `my_ip' config option is used as image cache dir
prefix to prevent races between nova-compute instances using the same
datastore.

The common practice of making nova-compute (with vmwareapi driver
chosen) HA is to have it run in active/passive mode controlled by
Pacemaker.  In that case Pacemaker can move nova-compute instance to
another host, should something happen to the original one, which
effectively will cause change of the IP address - thus, all cached
images will have to be re-downloaded again, despite the fact they are
still there in the datastore and still belong to this particular
nova-compute instance.

I02e758af19cf3a652a5c39d02904e73a1088fe60 made it possible to use the
`cache_prefix' config option to denote, which cache directory should
be used by a particular nova-compute instance. As long as we set the
same `cache_prefix' value for all nova-compute processes running in
active/passive mode, the cache directory will be the same on every
host.

Closes-Bug: #1482121

(cherry-picked from 7f064e855378e3ade9988170af506b2dd180f32e)

subject: Fix test_misc for WebOb 1.5
commit_message:
Fix test_misc for WebOb 1.5

WebOb 1.5 was released at 2015-10-11. With this new version,
webob.exc.WSGIHTTPException() constructor now fails with a KeyError
when the HTTP status code is 0.

test_exceptions_raise() of test_misc tries to instanciate all
exceptions of cinder.exception. The problem is that
ConvertedException uses a default HTTP status code of 0.

Modify the default HTTP status code of ConvertedException to 400 to
fix the unit test. The bug is only in the test,
cinder/api/openstack/wsgi.py copies an existing HTTP code:

    Fault(exception.ConvertedException(code=ex_value.code,  ...)

Closes-Bug: #1505153
Change-Id: I1aec8038774828d48da4b0e831b390e33243809a
(cherry picked from commit 867fccf833ffc597aa986cb6ff1b3b5c1101b9ba)
